task.title: Adding metadata to elements
task.shortdesc: You can use attributes to provide information about what product, audience, or platform an element applies to, or what revision it is part of.

taskbody.prereq: Before you use these attributes, you should work with your team to agree on a consistent set of values for use across your information set. Do not define your own values without consulting team mates, or your content may not build properly when it is reused.
taskbody.context: Use these attributes when you have content within a topic or a map that applies to only one or some of the products, platforms, or audiences for the topic or map as a whole.

step.cmd: Select the element you want to provide information for.
step.info: If the element doesn't have the attributes you need, try creating an element inside it, like a ph, that can hold the attributes instead.

step.cmd: Select the attribute for the information you want to provide:

chrow.chdesc: The product that the element applies to.
The platform (typically hardware, operating system, or both) that the element applies to.
The audience that the element applies to, Could be a user role (like administrator), experience level (novice), or combination (novice-admin).
The revision that the element is part of, if the topic has been revised and you want to track what stage particular content was added at.

step.cmd: Add a value or values to the attribute.
step.stepxmp: For example, audience="novice-admin expert-user" or platform="wintel".

step.cmd: For audience or product, add an equivalent element to the prolog metadata.
step.info: You can provide more information about your audience or product values in the topic's prolog, inside the metadata element. To ensure consistency, you can define the elements in one place for the entire information set, and then reuse them in topics that require them by using the conref attribute.

taskbody.result: Metadata attributes are inherited: they apply to any elements they contain as well. In a table, metadata for a column applies to all the cells in the column.
